Title:
Molecular Systematics of the Order Anaspidea Based on
Mitochondrial DNA Sequence (12S, 16S, and COI).
Abstract:
Fragments from three mitochondrial genes (12S, 16S, and
COI) were sequenced to reconstruct a molecular phylogeny of the
opisthobranch order Anaspidea. The molecular phylogeny supports the
placement of the genus Akera, a taxon previously regarded by some
authors as a cephalaspidean, within the Anaspidea. Incongruence between
the molecular data and the classifications based on morphology suggests
that some of the taxonomic characters (i.e., shell, parapodia fusion)
traditionally used for the classification of sea hares must be
reevaluated, since they maybe homoplastic. The ancestral nature of
Notarchus based on the molecular evidence suggests that homoplasy may be
an explanation for the morphological resemblance of this species to the
more derived sea hares with highly fused parapodia and concentrated
nerve ganglia. Finally, examples are given of how comparative studies of
the evolution of learning mechanisms in the anaspidean clade will
benefit from the phylogenetic hypothesis presented in this paper.
